item.title: Quick Brown Foxes
item.description:
My eyes aren’t what they used to be. A bog witch hasn’t turned them into tiny owls–they are still eyes. But they are becoming less good at being eyes.

Glasses may be in my future, but for now the issue is text. I can read books or the newspaper (because I’m a thousand) as well as I ever could, so it’s something specific to screen text. I have tried the obvious things to work around it; increasing font size and using dark mode where possible. But both options come with their own problems and annoying edge cases. It helped. A bit.

item.title: Recently
item.description:
An announcement and an apology.

Last month I got married. Surprisingly, given who I am as a person I was not anxious on the day, even when there was worry it would rain. I almost burst into hot tears the moment I saw Ceil in their dress and then again in the car, but I managed to keep it together for the ceremony. I was completely calm saying those words in front of people. It was a amazing day and even though it was overcast the gardens where we had ceremony were stunning. If you follow me on social media you will have already been bombarded with photos. And videos. Ciel has wonderfully documented the whole thing on Youtube. Needless to say but I’m saying it anyway, we are disgustingly happy and looking forward to many, many adventures together.

item.title: Recently
item.description:
So far this year has been taken up with planning for the upcoming wedding. It’s a lovely thing to be busy with, however it has left little brain–space for anything else. Writing—both real and this blog—have taken the backseat. Which is fine. But I’m looking forward to getting back into it now most things have settled into place.

There is a lot of work to be done on The Book: Copy–editing to do. Scenes to add or rewrite. We’ve found a new character who is demanding to be included. This written–during–pandemic book is taking up a lot of the post–pandemic.

item.title: Recently
item.description:
The first half of the year (now 9 months) has been eaten up with more than usual ill health, which culminated in a night time ride in an ambulance and a overnight stay in hospital. Thankfully, things have started to level out enough that I can concentrate on other things.

We managed to get Frances out to some folks a few months ago and honestly I’m find the whole beta reading thing kinda frustrating. Not because of the lovely people who decided to take it on. They are total sweethearts. But because it turns out I’m a very impatient person; I both want and dread feedback. Being extra sick and having else to focus on hasn’t helped.

item.title: Recently
item.description: For the last few weeks my part of the world has been submerged under water. There’s been sandbagging and phones pinging warnings and evacuation orders and helicopters going back and forth overhead. While our street remained dry—they put in a flood wall after the last major flood in the 90s but it had been untested until now—the south side of the river wasn’t as lucky and many homes are still under water and many others were damaged. This has all been not great for someone with an anxiety disorder. And writing went out the window. Which was closed. Because of the flood.

item.title: Recently
item.description:
Writing with another person can be a wonderful experience. Turns out that’s even more true when you’re actually sitting beside your co-author. And not just because they smell nice. I’m writing with my fiancé so that last part isn’t weird.

So far most of the work on our novel has been done over the internet, over distance, and asynchronously—each working when our brains felt capable. And that hasn’t been hard. The majority of our relationship happens over long distance so we’re used to that. And adding writing to that wasn’t too much of an ask. Actually, I was unsure how working in the same room would go. But sitting at the same desk and being able to simply point at things bought back the bounce and flow and fun that I didn’t realise had dissipated lately. So we’re excited again and the soft deadline of Christmas (2022) seems accomplishable (it’s a word).

item.title: In The White Room With Black Curtains (By The Station)
item.description:
I’ve been thinking a lot about scene description while attempting to write this book (yes that’s still happening). The question of how much scene setting is necessary? How much is enough? What’s too much? Too little? How many words are the difference between a scene that’s skeletal and one that’s chonky?

White Room Syndrome is the habit of creating a scenes that are so under-described, so lacking detail that it could be taking place in a featureless white-walled room in anywhere in the world. There is no sense of place. And the characters are doing their stuff in an empty void as if they’ve walked out of the picture like Daffy Duck in Duck Amuck. Obviously, scenes without specific, concrete locations are to be avoided like the plague (assuming people actually avoid plagues anymore). But, as a chronic under-writer, looking at thin scenes, it’s hard to not swing to the other extreme when fleshing out the story.

item.title: Words with Friend
item.description:
It started with a tweet

Which became a discussion

Then became a plan

We would write a book together

As you may know, this year my friend, Ciel, and I decided to attempt to write a novel together. Neither of us have written a novel before. And I haven’t co-written anything before. So we thought we should write some kind of work log in case we forget how we did this thing (or anyone ever asks about it). Here goes…

item.title: More Hands
item.description: So the experiment failed. Sort of. Last time I talked about changing to vim in an effort to save my hands. Text entry of course ended up the same and I could keep hitting my (paltry) word counts. But when editing, well, there are too many commands to hold in my head, and most of my editing time was spent consulting the cheat sheet on my desk. Editing became wading through sticky molasses. Had I stuck with it perhaps this need would lessen over time. Also, I kept falling back on using the mouse which is very much frowned on in vim circles. BUT it turns out my hands require the relief that comes with stopping and moving to the electric rodent.

item.title: Hands
item.description:
There are two things that became obvious while attempting NanoWriMo in 2020. First, that procrastination and global crisis are the most intimate of lovers and, second, my hands are no longer capable of typing at a computer like they once were.

As some of you may know, I have Muscular Dystrophy, which is a muscle weakening condition. What this means is, among myriad other things, my hands have been slowly worsening over time. Think of how your hands look when holding a gamepad, now take the pad away and imagine you can’t straighten your fingers out. Yep.
